A massive<br/>forest fire has been licking at its edges for more than a week. And<br/>officials fears high winds would whip up the flames today turning<br/>the community of 15,000 into a fire storm. But the winds never came<br/>and the town is safe for now. Salmon Arm sits in the midst of the<br/>Rocky Mountains east of Kamloops. CTV's Jed Kahane is there.</p><p>JED KAHANE [Reporter]: In the hills above Salmon Arm, there are<br/>so many fires burning it's impossible to fight them all on the<br/>ground. The bulk of the attack is coming from the air, more than a<br/>dozen helicopters and water bombers trying frantically to stop the<br/>flames from spreading. As dawn broke, the forecast held out little<br/>hope for anything but disaster. It called for winds gusting up to<br/>80 kilometres an hour, enough to push the fire right through the<br/>town.</p><p>KEN TEBO [Salmon Arm Fire Chief]: It's just about virtually<br/>impossible to stop by anybody.</p><p>KAHANE: That's why emergency officials ordered half the<br/>population to pack up and leave. Six thousand people headed for<br/>safety in nearby towns.</p><p>UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN [1]: We took our clothes and some food and,<br/>you know, things that are irreplaceable and we just left everything<br/>else in Salmon Arm.</p><p>UNIDENTIFIED MAN [1]: I just don't want all my stuff to be<br/>burned.</p><p>KAHANE: Others crammed into this trailer park, mapping the course<br/>of the fire and worrying about their homes.</p><p>UNIDENTIFIED MAN [2]: Just scary thinking about it. You know we<br/>moved up here in February and just bought this home. You know and<br/>we might not have a home.</p><p>UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN [2]: All you can do is just pray that the<br/>winds won't appear and the fire will go the other way.</p><p>KAHANE: By midday their prayers were answered. The strong winds<br/>never came.</p><p>MITZI BUSHNELL [BC Fire Service]: It's definitely good news.<br/>They're downscaling the closed frontal system coming in with the<br/>really strong winds. It doesn't sound to be quite so bad now.</p><p>KAHANE: Yet despite the break in the weather, the fight to save<br/>Salmon Arm is far from over. It hasn't rained here in nearly three<br/>weeks and the hot dry weather is expected to continue. Everyone<br/>here knows if the winds pick up the town will be in danger once<br/>again. That's why some people defied the evacuation order and<br/>stayed behind to protect their homes.</p><p>UNIDENTIFIED MAN [3]: We've been twelve hours a day putting out<br/>fires on the edges of the fields.</p><p>KAHANE: And there is still danger. That's why the evacuation<br/>order is being maintained and could last for days.</p><p>SGT DON BINDON [RCMP]: Fires before which didn't appear to be<br/>particularly threatening as last week showed in fact can turn on us<br/>very quickly.</p><p>KAHANE: In case that happens, the armed forces are now setting up<br/>camp. The rest of the town is still on alert, ready to pack up on<br/>a moment's notice. And they'll stay that way as long as the town is<br/>threatened. Jed Kahane, CTV News, Salmon Arm, BC.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source MARIPOSA, Calif. - The Latest on wildfires in California (all times local):

12:30 p.m.

Authorities say two more California firefighters have been injured while battling a stubborn and growing wildfire in steep terrain west of Yosemite National Park.

Fire spokesman Rich Eagan says the firefighters were hospitalized Friday after suffering back injuries. Both have been released and are expected to fully recover.

A total of four firefighters have been injured and one killed since the blaze broke out July 13.

Eagan says the fire is expanding to the north into inaccessible and rugged terrain within Sierra National Forest. It has burned about 42 square miles (110 square kilometres) of timber and is just 7 per cent contained.

A memorial service for firefighter Braden Varney, who was killed while operating a bulldozer on the fire line, will be held Monday in Modesto.

___

8:45 a.m.

A California forest fire just west of Yosemite National Park is steadily growing as crews work in blazing summer heat to protect mountain communities in the Sierra Nevada.

Officials said Saturday that the Ferguson fire is churning northward, sending up smoke that has been obscuring valley views in the park. Yosemite remains open, but one of its scenic routes, Glacier Point Road, is closed. The blaze that broke out July 13 has charred about 42 square miles (110 square kilometres) of timber. It's just 7 per cent contained.

Fast-acting firefighters got a handle on a wildfire that broke out Friday in Santa Barbara County, near Buellton. It's more than 30 per cent contained.

Forecasters warn that an extended period of high heat is brewing for much of the state, bringing increased fire danger.

urn:contentItem:7VV4-FH01-2R6R-5127-00000-00Most evacuees from Saskatchewan forest fire have returned to their homes2009-06-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSMost evacuees from Saskatchewan forest fire have returned to their homesCP

CANWOOD, Sask. _ Firefighters near Canwood, Sask., received some relief on Monday after light rain showers made battling fires that broke out over the weekend a little easier.

According to Jeanette Krayetski of the provincial wildfire program, the Canwood fire was covering about 17 square kilometres of land, more than doubling its size from Sunday.

''Essentially, this fire was wind-driven,'' she said of the jump in the fire's size. ''It was very smoky for firefighters to look and establish the fire perimeter.''

Seventy firefighters were on the ground along with 12 pieces of heavy equipment, several water bombers, three helicopters and help from volunteer firefighters.

Officials also closed Highway 55 as of early Monday afternoon, with traffic being re-routed through the old Canwood highway.

Provincial firefighters were also battling a blaze located in the Fort a la Corne provincial forest, about 60 kilometres east of Prince Albert.

Krayetski said the fire started around 4 p.m. Sunday, and spread to cover 200 hectares of forest land.

She said the fire also came close to the Shore Gold exploration site, but a fire break was put around the main camp as fire crews fought off the blaze.

Joe Dickson, manager of investor relations for Shore Gold, said the company was watching the fire's progress with cautious optimism, adding that the camp is not currently in use.

''From what we understand and the information the ministry has given us, the fire is north of us,'' he said.

Provincial fire commissioner Duane McKay said one of the large issues being dealt with is the amount of smoke produced by the fires, especially the one near Canwood.

McKay said health officials are helping them to pass information out to those who are living in the area of the fires about the effects of inhaling the smoke.

The total number of forest fires the province has dealt with this year stands at 248, up 60 fires over this time last year. Fire conditions in the Prince Albert area are currently listed as moderate, an upgrade over the recent spate of extremely dry conditions.

By Monday, most of the people who had been evacuated from their rural homes near Canwood were allowed to return to their homes.

No one has been hurt but there has been property damage.

Tanya Almen lost three buildings on her property but her house was not among them.

''It's depressing but it hasn't hit home yet,'' she said. ''I had a beautiful yard and it's all gone.''

(Prince Albert Herald, CTV Prince Albert)

(AP) _ A Russian university student was charged with burning the U.S. flag in a fire that charred about a hectare of woodland in northern Virginia.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AP</p></bodyText></section><p>Oleg Asserin, 18, of Falls Church, Va., was arrested Tuesday on a felony charge of setting a fire capable of spreading and a misdemeanour charge of burning the U.S. flag.</p><p>Virginia is among 48 states that still have flag-desecration laws on the books, even though the U.S. Supreme Court has ruled flag-burning is constitutionally protected speech.</p><p>Fairfax County Commonwealth's Attorney Robert Horan said Friday he will decide whether to pursue the flag-burning charge after he reviews the case.</p><p> We'll wait and see what the facts are,'' Horan said.</p><p>Firefighters from Fairfax County and neighbouring Montgomery County, Md., responded to the fire Sunday morning. It burned about a hectare of brush near the George Washington Memorial Parkway before it was extinguished Tuesday.</p><p>Firefighters found a charred U.S. flag among the damage.</p><p>Fire department spokesman Dan Schmidt said authorities checked medical facilities and found Asserin receiving treatment for burns on his arms and upper body.</p><p>Fire officials said they did not believe Asserin was expressing support for recent terrorist acts. The motivation for the burning was unclear.</p><p>Asserin, who is Russian, attends George Mason University. A message left at the school's public-relations office was not returned late Friday.</p><p>At his arraignment, Asserin was ordered held pending a psychiatric evaluation. A preliminary hearing is Dec. 12.</p><p>Kent Willis, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Virginia, said the flag-burning law, enacted in 1960, is unconstitutional and the ACLU will seek to have the charge dismissed if prosecutors don't drop it.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Toronto singer-songwriter and fingerstyle guitarist, Shawna Caspi, is touring in British Columbia and will be making a stop in Chilliwack at the Acoustic Emporium on Feb. 9.

Although she performs solo, there's a whole band under her fingertips. She believes in poetry and the power of one person and one instrument, accompanying herself with a remarkable lyrical fingerpicking guitar style.

Her performances capture audiences with grace and intimacy, whether the setting is a living room, a festival stage, or the bar car of a passenger train. Caspi loves the landscapes of her travels, and while weaving them into her songs, she has also been portraying them on canvases, painting one-of-a-kind works of art inspired by the rich scenery she sees on tour.

She's been on the road throughout Canada and the U.S. for the past year and a half promoting her latest album, Forest Fire, which is a collection of songs about burning things down and building them up again.

When the words get heavy, they are held up to the light of love and gratitude. Caspi strives to be unafraid, to embolden quieted voices, to tell the truth above all else.

Caspi has played at the Blue Skies Music Festival, the Ottawa Grassroots Festival, the Shelter Valley Folk Festival, the Kingsville Folk Music Festival and the Summerfolk Festival in Ontario, ArtsWells in British Columbia, and the Deep Roots Music Festival and Harmony Bazaar Festival in Nova Scotia, as well as concert series including the Circle of Friends Coffeehouse in Franklin, MA, Six String Concerts in Columbus, OH, the me&thee coffeehouse in Marblehead, MA, and John Platt's On Your Radar in NYC.

She has performed in Chilliwack in the past at Tractorgrease, but this is her first time playing the Acoustic Emporium series.

The show is Saturday, Feb. 9 at Acoustic Emporium (45892 Wellington Ave.) at 7 p.m. Admission: $15. Tickets available at https://tinyurl.com/emporiumfeb9. More info: 604-793-1925, acousticemporium.org, shawnacaspi.com/gigs.

PANAMA CITY, FLA.-Trees brought down by Hurricane Michael's ferocious winds took a heavy toll on life, property and the timber industry in the heavily forested Florida Panhandle, where $1.3 billion in timber was lost, authorities said Friday.

A firefighter became the latest death attributed to the storm when he was killed by a falling tree while helping clear debris with family members more than a week after Michael blew ashore with 410 km/h winds.

Fire co-ordinator Brad Price, 49, of Wewahitchka was on his tractor when he was killed Thursday, the Gulf County Sheriff's Office said on its official Facebook page.

"We love you, grieve with you, and are praying for all of you," Gulf County firefighters said on their Facebook page.

That brought the storm's death toll in Florida to 25, and 35 overall across the South - where, in addition to tree falls, deaths came when the storm decimated homes with winds and storm surge, cut power to those reliant on electricity for medical conditions and swept away cars in flash floods.

Florida Agriculture Commissioner Adam Putnam said that along with the $1.3 billion in timber losses, pulp mills, sawmills and other production facilities were damaged in 11 of the top timber-producing counties in state.

Officials also were concerned that downed trees could pose a fire hazard.

urn:contentItem:58T6-K811-JDV5-F3CG-00000-00'As dark a day as I can remember'2013-07-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A10'As dark a day as I can remember'Lightning-sparked blaze killed 19 firefighters in Arizona forest fire; 50 homes engulfedThe Associated Press

As the windblown blaze suddenly swept toward them, an elite crew of firefighting "Hotshots" desperately rushed to break out their emergency shelters and take cover on the ground under the heat-resistant fabric.

By the time the flames had passed, 19 men lay dead in the United States's biggest loss of firefighters in a wildfire in 80 years.

The tragedy Sunday evening all but wiped out the 20-member Granite Mountain Hotshots, a unit based in the small town of Prescott, Prescott Fire Chief Dan Fraijo said as the last of the bodies were retrieved from the mountain. Only one member survived, and that was because he was moving the unit's truck at the time, authorities said.

The deaths plunged the town into mourning, and Arizona's governor called it "as dark a day I can remember" and ordered flags at half-mast.

The lightning-sparked fire - which had exploded to about 35 square kilometres by Monday morning - destroyed about 50 homes and threatened 250 others in and around Yarnell, a town of 700 people in the mountains about 135 kilometres northwest of Phoenix, the Yavapai County Sheriff's Department said.

Residents huddled in shelters and restaurants, watching their homes burn as flames lit up the night in the forest above the town.

It was unclear exactly how the firefighters became trapped. Southwest incident team leader Clay Templin said the crew and its commanders were following safety protocols, and it appears the fire's erratic nature overwhelmed them.

Brian Klimowski, meteorologist in charge of the National Weather Service's Flagstaff office, said there was a sudden increase and shift in wind around the time of the tragedy. It's not known how powerful the winds were, but they were enough to cause the fire to grow from 200 acres to about 2,000 in a few hours.

The United States has 110 Hotshot crews, according to the U.S. Forest Service website. They typically have about 20 members each. As a last-resort effort at survival, members are trained to dig into the ground and cover themselves with a one-man, bag-like shelter made of fire-resistant material, Fraijo said.

"It's an extreme measure that's taken under the absolute worst conditions," Fraijo said.

The flames apparently enveloped the shelters. Autopsies were scheduled to determine how the firefighters died.

By Keith McNeill

Clearwater and Blackpool fire departments have been receiving aid during the present forest fire emergency from other departments, including Blue River, Barriere and Merritt.

"One of the really good things that we're seeing is other people coming to support us," said Clearwater mayor John Harwood, commenting on the firefighters and their vehicles from other jurisdictions.

"People are getting a positive feeling at a critical time."

The mayor noted that search and rescue volunteers from places such as Kamloops, Barriere, Shuswap had gone door-to-door with staff from BC Parks, Conservation Officer Service, Blackwell Park Operations and RCMP to deliver evacuation alert notices in Clearwater and Blackpool.

Three public information meetings have been held at Clearwater Secondary School since the fire emergency began on July 7, he said.

The latest one, which was held on Sunday evening, July 16, had the largest attendance so far.

As of Monday morning, a video of the meeting had had about 9,000 views.

"That's definitely getting the meeting out there," he said.

Harwood said the fire situation is hurting the local business community hard.

"This will affect the whole community and its well-being for a while," the mayor predicted.

sites</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY TERRI THEODORE</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">VANCOUVER (CP) _ The biggest fire scorching British Columbia is licking flames ever closer to a 19th-century aboriginal longhouse and has already destroyed several historic native sites, says a band member.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Linda Price, natural resources director for the Ulkatcho band, also said aboriginal gravesites within Tweedsmuir Park and cultural sites where band members have traditionally fished and gathered food are at risk and traditional trails have already been destroyed.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But the natives _ like many of the 60 residents who have been evacuated from their homes in the area _ are critical of the Forest Service's decision to let the fire burn for a month.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Residents complained after the fire destroyed the 80-year-old pioneer cabin last weekend.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"The policy of letting the fires go in parks is not one we completely support because of the threat that it poses to us, our cultural sites and our homes and our lives here in Anahim Lake,'' said Laurie Vaughn, spokeswoman for the band.</p><p>"There needs to be a lot more co-operation from the parks branch in working with Ulkatcho. We've got a number of homesteads that are in the park.''</p><p>Fire officials have repeatedly defended their decision to let the fire in Tweedsmuir Park, about 320 kilometres northwest of Vancouver, burn.</p><p>It broke out in June on a steep area that was too dangerous for firefighters on the ground the access. A waterbomber assault on the early stages of the blaze was also ineffective because of the fire's location.</p><p>B.C. Forests Minister Mike de Jong said Friday he understands the concerns of aboriginals.</p><p>"Of course they're upset,'' he said. "If things that are of importance to someone are lost, you would expect them to be upset.''</p><p>Officials will conduct a review of how the fire was handled but de Jong said the fire situation in Tweedsmuir Park was a long time coming.</p><p>The park is Ground Zero for the pine beetle infestation that has damaged large tracts of B.C. forest.</p><p>De Jong said for 10 years, the infestation has been killing off trees, leaving tinder-dry dead trees perfect for forest fire fuel.</p><p>When the infestation first broke out, the then-NDP government originally contracted a forestry company to log the damaged trees. But the contract was eventually cancelled, leaving the beetles to spread and resulting in a strongly-worded court judgment against the province.</p><p>The beetle damage, the difficulties fighting the fire in the steep terrain of the park, and half a century of efforts to stamp out forest fires has meant there's a lot of fuel on the forest floor, de Jong said.</p><p>"We have to address that,'' he said. "But we're not going to change the fuel load issue overnight and things like prescribed burns are part of the recipe for addressing it.</p><p>"But again, you have to make a choice. Do we have some smoke in the spring or the fall or a hell of a lot more smoke in August when it's more dangerous.</p><p>"I know what I prefer.''</p><p>A report into the devastating fire season last year recommended the province do controlled burns and possibly some selective logging of provincial parks in an effort to reduce the dead wood and other forest debris. However, such actions are strongly opposed by environmental groups.</p><p>The Tweedsmuir Park fire, now known as the Lonesome Lake fire, exploded last week when winds whipped it up and it has continued to grow steadily all week. By Friday, it was estimated to be about 160 square kilometres in size, up from 140 square kilometres the day before.</p><p>There are about 100 residences on Charlotte Lake, all but 12 of them summer homes. Sixty people have been evacuated but have been allowed back periodically to check on their properties and to pack out more belongings.</p><p>"It's a very difficult fire,'' said Jim Price, the superintendent of the forest protection branch of the Ministry of Forests.</p><p>"Our crews are working very hard on the fire and they're working with the communities in the area on keeping them informed on what we're doing out there.''</p><p>At times, the fire has been classified a Rank 6, the worst of its kind.</p><p>Rank 6 fires are characterized by "what we call flame lanes 400 feet above the trees themselves,'' said Price.</p><p>"Sometimes it creates its own weather. Sometimes it will take large chunks of trees, throwing them in the air hundreds of feet, maybe even thousands of feet.</p><p>"It's a very devastating and energy-packed situation that we're aware of and when that happens, like I say, you have to make sure that all of our crews are safe.''</p><p>Another 1,300 people in the Nimpo Lake area of the Interior have also remained on alert from the 23-square-kilometre Klinaklini Valley fire, which has remained stable in size all week.</p><p>"It's mostly challenging because of the weather we've had lately,'' said Price. "It's been very dry and windy and the forecast for this long weekend is for continued warm, dry weather.''</p><p>De Jong said 2004 is shaping up to be even worse than last year in terms of the number of fires and the cost of fighting them.</p><p>There are 369 fires burning in the province compared with 196 at this time last year.</p><p>Fighting them has cost $80 million so far, compared with $34 spent by the same time last year.</p><p>However, last year, August fires in the Okanagan and the Interior destroyed more than 300 homes and forced tens of thousands of people to flee their homes in Kelowna and Barriere.</p><p>Three aerial tanker pilots were killed.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5SNK-75N1-DY9S-T442-00000-00After the fire: Some trails, campgrounds reopen in Waterton Lakes National Park2018-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisTRAVEL,PRAIRIES/BCAfter the fire: Some trails, campgrounds reopen in Waterton Lakes National ParkMore of Waterton Lakes National Park open to publicThe Canadian Press

WATERTON, Alta. - Parks Canada has reopened more trails and campgrounds in Waterton Lakes National Park which was devastated by a forest fire last fall.

The blaze in the southern Alberta park in September consumed more than 190 square kilometres, including about 80 per cent of the park's popular hiking trails.

The park was put under a mandatory evacuation on Sept. 8 that lasted for two weeks.

Parks Canada says 50 kilometres of trails have been reopened.

Three backcountry campgrounds are also available to the public.

The agency says staff first had to repair damaged and destroyed benches and footbridges, as well as cut and clear fallen and burned trees.

Areas that have been reopened include the Bertha Falls, Bertha Lake, Crandell Lake Loop, Horseshoe Basin and Lakeshore trails.

The Bertha Bay, Bertha Lake and Boundary Bay backcountry campgrounds are also ready, although Bertha Lake may be affected by snowmelt.

The townsite and lake areas were already open.

The Crandell Mountain campground, Bear's Hump Trail, Akamina Parkway and Cameron Lake day-use area remain closed.

Parks Canada says it's too early to say when those areas might reopen and is asking visitors to stay away. Entering a closed area can result in a fine.

Flames swept as far as the edges of the townsite last fall. The windswept Prince of Wales Hotel, which was built in 1927 on a bluff overlooking Waterton Lake, was also threatened. But the national historic site was ultimately saved.

The Waterton Lakes natural area continues across the border into Montana where it is called Glacier National Park.

urn:contentItem:5X17-1D11-F103-301R-00000-00B.C. greenhouse gas emissions continue to increase2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisBUSINESSB.C. greenhouse gas emissions continue to increaseTom Fletcher

B.C.'s greenhouse gas emissions increased again in 2017, despite reduced carbon dioxide intensity from key sources including oil and gas refining and road transportation.

The B.C. environment ministry released its latest data Monday, reporting a 1.7 per cent increase over 2016 in carbon dioxide equivalent emissions. After accounting for one million tonnes of carbon offsets from forest management projects, net emissions were calculated at 64.5 million tonnes for the year.

The environment ministry reports that emissions were reduced in oil and gas extraction, road transport, electricity and heat production. Sectors with increases included manufacturing, off-road transport, residential and agriculture.

B.C.'s strong economy and increasing population work against reductions in greenhouse gas intensity, with 251 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent produced for every million dollars of gross domestic product in 2017. That's a reduction of 2.5 per cent in intensity, showing improved efficiency.

Evironment Minister George Heyman said the government's CleanBC measures, requiring less carbon-intensive fuels and increasing building efficiency and electric vehicle use, were not in place to influence the 2017 data.

That was the year that the NDP government replaced the former B.C. Liberal government, which had gone five years without increasing the province's carbon tax, which could also have improved B.C.'s results, Heyman said.

RELATED: B.C. carbon tax increases to $40 per tonne for 2019

RELATED: B.C. carbon tax revenues go toward home upgrades

The official B.C. total does not include the effect of a record year for area burned by wildfires in 2017. The provincial data show wildfire emissions for the year of 176,550 tonnes, almost three times total emissions from the officially measured sources. For 2016, the wildfire emissions were 12,500 tonnes.

Heyman said B.C.'s carbon tax measurement conforms to international standards, which do not include measuring forest fire activity because it is beyond human control.

B.C. Green Party leader Andrew Weaver said the province's CleanBC plan, which he developed along with Premier John Horgan, is having an effect, but it's not enough.

"Our individual carbon footprint per British Columbian barely comes in under our neighbours to the south, by a measly 12 per cent," Weaver said. "These numbers show us that we are not the concerned environmental stewards that we think we are, and it is because we have had governments that fail to regulate industry and fail to implement a vision for a new, green economy rooted in sustainable practices."

Forest fires halt Musselwhite operation: "Goldcorp (G.TO) announced the evacuation of the majority of its 380 employees at its Musselwhite mine located in northwestern Ontario, due to forest fires in the surrounding area. Mining operations have been halted and the main power supply to the minesite has been lost as due to power lines being destroyed by the fires. G indicated to us that it does not expect any material damage to occur to the minesite itself as it is located in a relatively deforested area, giving local crews to the ability to better contain any fire that moves into closer proximity (currently fires are 30km away). We also note the minesite's above surface facilities are largely contained in concrete and non-flammable materials. Additionally, fire crews may perform controlled fires to provide a further buffer zone and fire crews are safeguarding the plant and other important facilities. Goldcorp has maintained a skeleton staff at Musselwhite to monitor essential operations and coordinate with local fire crews. G will provide additional clarity on expected production impacts next week."

Power to the site and lack of personnel the main issue currently. "Based on our conversation with G, we expect a two to four week production impact as power lines are repaired and employees are gradually returned to the minesite. We estimate four weeks of down time would result in approximately 23kozs of gold production being deferred, and will cause a $0.04/sh reduction to our $3.59/sh 2011FY operating cashflows (OCF). As G currently trades at 15x 2011 price to operating cashflow (P/OCF) we anticipate ~$0.60/sh impact will result. A four week deferral would have minimal impact to our NAV as Musselwhite represents 4% of our DCF for Goldcorp. We were forecasting 273kozs of gold at Musselwhite in 2011."

This is not a Meadowbank event: "We expect there may be fears that this fire could have similar impacts to that of Agnico-Eagle's (AEM.TO) March 10th, 2011 fire at its Meadowbank mine. However, we point out the fact that AEM's fire started internally in the kitchen facilities while this fire is from an external source whose impacts can be mitigated with advance warning."

urn:contentItem:5PP3-5JK1-F105-6369-00000-00Responding to climate change means thinking differently2017-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisOPINIONResponding to climate change means thinking differentlyKeith McNeill

A few weeks ago the Times published an opinion piece by the Rambling Man, Jim Lamberton, titled, "Former faller says wildfire response mismanaged."

It certainly resonated with a lot of people.

In terms of comments on social media, it had the biggest response by far of any article we've published.

It resonated with your editor as well. There are quite a few points that Jim and I agree on, although I think he was a little too hard on BC Wildfire Service.

There is one major point, however, where we differ diametrically.

READ MORE: Former faller says wildfire response mismanaged

READ MORE: Wildfire preparation and response inadequate

READ MORE: 2017 was driest summer ever recorded in Kamloops

DO MORE: Petition for a referendum on carbon fee-and-dividend for Canada

That is in his final paragraph where he wrote, "If the true figures were published, I think you'd have to admit that this catastrophic fire season is not about global warming. It's about mismanagement."

No, Jim, this year's fire season was all about global warming.

This part of B.C. is about 1.1ºC warmer now than it was 100 years ago.

That's the B.C. Ministry of Environment's estimate . Talk with old-timers about how we don't get the -40ºC winters like we used to and they will agree.

Warmer temperatures mean more extreme fire behavior. If you don't believe that, then I have a bridge that I would like to sell you.

This is important.

If last summer's extreme fire season was just the result of mismanagement, then if we could just return to the good old days when local loggers took the lead on fighting forest fires, then all would be well.

On the other hand, if climate change was the major factor, then in coming years we can expect to see more of the same and even worse.

The Future Forests Strategy done for the Kamloops Timber Area a few years ago predicted that, with climate change, there will be bunch grass and sagebrush extending to north of Clearwater Lake by 2080.

In other words, all the trees we see today on the floor of the North Thompson Valley will be gone - or at least highly stressed.

Where will they go? The most likely scenario will be fire.

Last week's Fire Prevention Week supplement briefly mentioned the Peshtigo Fire , the most devastating forest forest fire in American history.

On Oct. 8, 1871, it roared through northeast Wisconsin, burning 16 towns, killing 1,200 to 2,500 people (estimates only, because so many records were lost), and destroying about 500,000 ha of forest.

The town of Peshtigo was burned to the ground within one hour. The firestorm created such strong winds that rail cars and homes were thrown into the air.

We don't hear about the Peshtigo Fire because, 400 km to the south, the Great Chicago Fire began the same day, killing 300 and destroying nine sq. km of the city.

Also that same day, the towns of Holland, Manistee and Port Huron, Michigan burned.

The following day, Oct. 9, fire swept through the downtown area of Urbana, Illinois, about 230 km south of Chicago.

That complex of fires was an extreme event and we haven't had anything like if for over 100 years.

Let's say that it was a one in 200 year event when it happened.

What is the probability that something similar will happen now? One in 100 years? One in 50?

If we accept that climate change is real, then we also need to accept that the probability of such extreme events has increased and will continue to increase.

In other words, we ain't seen nothing yet.

As people who live in a forested area, we should be concerned.

What kind of emergency response system will we need to cope?

Lamberton is correct in that we need to get away from this over-reliance on centralized systems.

If a forest fire can destroy a town in an hour, then we can't rely on Victoria to provide help in time.

Steve Murray and the volunteer fire crew that formed spontaneously in Upper Clearwater last summer have the right idea, although I think even they are a little daunted as they realize the challenge they face.

The fact is, every town in Canada should have its own well-organized and properly funded civil defense organization. Climate change will bring us not just increased forest fires, but also flooding, windstorms and other calamities.

A million dollars spent on forest fuel reduction around communities is all very well, but in 20 years most of the effect will be gone. A million dollars spent on sprinkler systems, pumps and ongoing training on how to use them will still be of value 20 years later.

We also need to get away from this over-reliance on evacuating people everywhere.

Last summer, over 45,000 people were evacuated due to wildfires in B.C.

Although the host communities were overwhelmingly welcoming, experience elsewhere has shown that that welcome quickly wears off if the evacuees keep coming back or stay too long.

There is also the problem that the host communities can be ordered evacuated themselves.

Last summer, many people were evacuated to Prince George. That city, however, is rated as having a greater risk of wildfire damage than was Fort McMurray.

It would be far better if conditions were created that would allow the residents of communities, small and large, to stay in those communities.

That would mean creating refuges in schools, hospitals and so on where the residents could take shelter.

When you consider that such refuges might need to be able to withstand hurricane-force winds in a firestorm, it becomes apparent that the task is not trivial.

Nevertheless, it would be better to be in a building that was half-prepared than to be caught by a forest fire out on the highway while trying to evacuate.

Surviving human-caused climate change requires that we think differently. Learning new ways to deal with potentially catastrophic forest fires would be a good place for us to start.

It was eerie, like a funeral. There was silence and hardly anyone moved or spoke.''</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Nylander's prize was one of three announced Wednesday.</p><p>Debra Brash of the Victoria Times Colonist won the enterprise photo of the year and Chuck Stoody, a longtime CP photographer, captured the sports prize.</p><p>Brash won for her shot, taken from across a workout studio, of a group of people doing yoga, some of them suspended above the floor from wall apparatus.</p><p>"It didn't make me want to take up yoga,'' Brash said with a laugh. "It's a great honour for me to win this award since it's voted on by my peers.''</p><p>Each winner receives $1,000.</p><p>The awards were selected from the 12 winners of CP's Picture of the Month contest. urn:contentItem:5TDP-XWY1-F103-327S-00000-00Grade 5 students learn about the land at Forestry Days2018-10-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYGrade 5 students learn about the land at Forestry Days

Submitted

The Ministry of Forests, Lands, and Natural Resource Operations, and partners in the forest industry hosted their annual Forestry Days at Kokanee Creek Provincial Park last month.

Grade 5 students from School District 8, as well as from private schools in the region, were invited to partake in a full day of activities and outdoor forest fun.

Organizer Russell Holitzki, a registered professional forester, explained that the annual event is meant to encourage greater public awareness of Canada's forests. "We want to share the values of the forest with the kids in the hope that they learn a few things today, and have some fun too!" said Holitzki.

Students from Redfish Elementary and Brent Kennedy were happy to keep the beat with drums and accompany Gail Higginbottom, district principal of aboriginal education and Danica Weager, district indigenization co-ordinator in an opening indigenous song. Aboriginal academic success teacher Andrea Mann was also instrumental in school visits to Brent Kennedy Elementary in advance of the event.

Higginbottom was honoured to be invited to open the event with an indigenous welcome. "Today is a celebration of traditional ways of knowing, and land-based learning," she said.

The remainder of the day required volunteers from the ministry, the Kootenay Lake Forestry Centre and multiple forestry contractors running stations that groups of students could cycle through. Approximately 270 students discovered more about logging, wood products and safety, aging and forest art, wildfire and forest health. There was a free lunch provided by Kalesnikoff Lumber and a scavenger hunt too.

First established in the 1920s as Forest Fire Prevention Week, the awareness campaign has grown to include the many layers of forest management and is now known as National Forest Week, which is co-ordinated nationally by the Canadian Institute of Forestry and in B.C. by the National Forest Week BC Coalition, a group of volunteers from the Association of BC Forest Professionals.

urn:contentItem:5VVK-G1K1-F103-31JS-00000-00YG to develop a capital plan to thwart forest fires2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisNEWSYG to develop a capital plan to thwart forest fires

The Southern Lakes Region is one area Yukon government-backed research has identified as being at high risk of a forest fire.

Military drills are slated to occur this spring in case a fire does eventually break out there, said John Streicker, minister of community services.

"We think there's a lot of risk. The Southern Lake forest is a very old, very mature forest and we're very concerned about that risk creating an interface fire," he told reporters on April 2. "That's exactly why we chose Operation Nanook to go right in that place."

Streicker, whose riding includes Southern Lakes, said he has received a report that pinpoints sensitive areas where fires could start. A capital plan would be based off the research. He said the findings could eventually be released.

The idea would be to gradually turn a coniferous forest into a more deciduous one, Streicker said. The work would be ongoing.

"The fire risk is very different across those two."

The issue came up during question period, with Yukon Party MLA Brad Cathers asking what strategies the Liberals are working with to curb future fires, including targeted harvesting of coniferous trees and increasing farmland, which can provide a firebreak.

Streicker said he's been working with Ministers Ranj Pillai and Richard Mostyn to figure out how to lessen fuel loads and turn it into biomass.

"We are doing many things. We are rebuilding the Whitehorse air tanker base starting this year. We have lined up Operation Nanook with the Canadian military to happen this spring so that we can work with our firefighters as part of that exercise. There is a range of things that we're doing."

In response to Cathers' question about farmland, Pillai, minister of energy, mines and resources, told the legislative assembly about an agricultural policy update.

"It has been about 10 years since we have had a renewal in our agricultural policy work. Our team is going back out for discussions with the Yukon Agricultural Association, Growers of Organic Food Yukon and others. There is a language that we are looking to ground-truth, and this is really about what happens with agricultural lands, and therefore, that will define how we develop in our near future," he said.

urn:contentItem:5TG0-S1H1-JDH1-C4RH-00000-00Chief of Cowichan Tribes says work being done to address housing, jobs and more2018-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisNEWSChief of Cowichan Tribes says work being done to address housing, jobs and more

A lot of work is underway to assist members of Cowichan Tribes, according to Chief William Seymour.

Seymour said the band is currently working toward greater autonomy in jurisdictional and legislative matters that is intended to allow Cowichan Tribes to have more of a say in many of the band's issues.

He said Cowichan Tribes is one of three First Nations in B.C. that was recently chosen by the province to begin a process of beginning to take over some of these responsibilities, and believes it will have a positive impact on band members.

"We are now having regular meetings with the province and the federal government, and we're working together to see this happen," he said.

"But several aspects of this process could take up to five years to complete."

Seymour was responding to concerns that were raised at an attempted blockade of the band's offices by some members of Cowichan Tribes in Duncan on Oct. 4.

RELATED STORY: BLOCKADE PLANNED FOR COWICHAN TRIBES' BAND OFFICE

Sam Wilson, a spokesman for the couple of dozen band members who participated in the protest, had said there is a "serious failure of fiduciary duty" to Cowichan Tribes members by council, and they are living in a crisis situation as a result.

He said the protesters were demanding to see all the band's financial statements.

Wilson also said there are concerns around children being seized from families, the issue that many land owners in the band are being pushed off their properties even though they have certificates of possession for the land, inadequate housing and ongoing unemployment among band members.

RELATED STORY: PROTESTERS GET THE EAR OF COWICHAN TRIBES WITH ATTEMPTED BLOCKADE

Seymour said the Child and Family Services department that operates on the reserve operates under governmental guidelines, but the band tries to ensure the children taken from homes are not sent far and wide.

"The safety of our children comes first and our first choice is to have them go to other family members," he said.

"We are working with the families and applied for funding for more staff and resources to ensure that, unless the children are in serious danger in their homes, then they can stay there. We're looking at changing some of these ministry policies when we are more in charge of our own legislative and jurisdictional issues. I can't discuss the individual reasons why the children were taken from their homes because the files are confidential and I can't discuss them."

As for band members being pushed off their legally owned properties, Seymour said he knows of no such actions.

"We respect certificates of possession and I have no idea why that has come up as an issue," he said.

Seymour said dealing with housing issues is a slow process, but work is ongoing.

He said the band has been meeting with banks regarding interest rates and other issues around band members.

"A lot of banks won't give our members mortgages on reserve land because they can't have the option of coming onto the reserve and take it away [in the event of a default], as they would outside the reserve," he said.

"We're looking at a number of different scenarios to deal with our housing issues, including building apartment buildings and townhouses, and we're costing them out. One question is if we finance any of these projects through the banks, how long do we have to repay the loan? It has to come at a low cost."

Seymour said another housing issue is the number of homes on the reserve that are boarded up due to mould issues.

He said Cowichan Tribes has recently come to an agreement with Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada in which the department agreed to pay 80 per cent of the costs of the mould removal and clean up of the homes.

"We're hoping to have someone hired to assess these homes soon," Seymour said.

As for unemployment issues, Seymour said the band does have a small department that assists members train for and find employment.

But he said it's currently a one-person department when two or three people are needed to meet the band's needs.

However, he pointed out a number of employment opportunities that band members have taken advantage of recently, including waste-energy projects, forestry work, and forest fire crews.

"We had nine crews working during the forest fire season this year, with each having up to eight people on a crew," he said.

Enterprises and John Clunies-Ross.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- The government blames the company for starting a 1998 fire that cost $6 million to fight and covered 3,200 hectares near Haines Junction, Yukon.</p><p>Malcolm Florence, a lawyer with the territory's federal Crown office, said he believes this is the first time such a suit has been launched in the territory.</p><p>Florence said the government is also working on at least four other files, although he said the preferred method of resolution is always through out-of-court settlements.</p><p>He said one blaze currently "under review'' is the 1999 Burwash Landing fire, which an RCMP investigation found was most likely caused by an employee of the Yukon government.</p><p>The suit brought against Clunies-Ross and A.J. Enterprises claims costs "for the negligence of the defendants, and each of them, in igniting, or causing to be ignited, said fire and for failing to control said fire,'' according to court documents.</p><p>The suit might still be settled out of court, said Florence, but after initial discussions, the government decided to pursue court action in the interim.</p><p>Florence said before filing such a suit, there is a full review of the fire, including its source, whether it was fought properly, how large a part weather played in the outcome and if anything could have been done differently by the government to reduce damage.</p><p>Florence said pursuing civil litigation often enables settlement discussions to move ahead faster.</p><p>He pegged the cost of litigation at anywhere between $5,000 to $300,000, depending on the size of the file and time it takes to reach a resolution.</p><p>The 1998 Haines Junction fire eventually drew 110 firefighters, including firefighters and air tankers from Ontario.</p><p>A report from the Department of Indian Affairs said high winds and drought conditions meant the fire remained a concern throughout the summer.</p><p>Paula Webber, a spokeswoman for the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, said 1998 was a particularly bad year for forest fires.</p><p>She estimated the total cost for fire suppression in 1998 at $30 million, or over three times the department's annual forest fire budget of $9.6 million.</p><p>Of 190 fires that year, 106 were caused by people, which Webber said was "abnormally high.''</p><p>It cost $2.2 million to fight the Burwash Landing and the fire cost several aboriginal people their homes last year.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - About 400 residents were allowed to return home Friday after a forest fire that threatened this Northern Ontario city was brought under control.</p><p>Timmins fire Chief Lester Cudmore said a state of emergency would remain in effect in Mountjoy and Ogden townships.</p><p>"When you're talking about a bush fire, it can flare up even when it looks like it's out.''</p><p>The fire, burning along a 200-hectare front and whipped up by high winds, jumped the 120-metre-wide Mattagami River and a highway. For a while late Thursday, it looked like flames might engulf the city three kilometres away.</p><p>No serious injuries were reported, but the flames destroyed hydro poles and a few sheds.</p><p>Sixteen fire crews were at the scene, along with police and personnel from the Ministry of Natural Resources. Two water bombers, two bulldozers and two helicopters were involved in the firefighting effort.</p><p>"The force of the water coming from the water bombers was so strong that it actually snapped trees in half, but it saved the properties,'' said Ben Legouffe, a Ministry spokesman.</p><p>About 400 people from two trailer parks west of the city and residents from around Baker Lake and the Mattagami River were evacuated Thursday.</p><p>They were permitted to return to their homes Friday, but were asked to stay near their properties and stay clear of the fire.</p><p>"The (Ministry) has requested citizens not directly involved with the fire to refrain from going into the area in order to allow fire crews to perform their work without interference,'' said Timmins information officer Jack Watson.</p><p>Dwight Eide, the Ministry's emergency response co-ordinator, said no open flames were visible Friday, but added the situation could quickly change.</p><p>The cause of the blaze is under investigation.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - Residents of a northern B.C. native community were forced from their homes Sunday when a forest fire raced towards their town.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The 250 people of Ware left on buses, trucks and aircraft by 1 a.m. as the fire came within four kilometres of the town, said Wendy Stewart, spokeswoman for the B.C. Forest Service.</p><p>The fire, apparently started by someone near a road Saturday afternoon, mushroomed to 1,500 hectares from 150 hectares in less than 24 hours, racing through tinder-dry forest.</p><p>"The valley bottom is mature pine and as it moved away from the river up the mountain it was into spruce and balsam, which can be a vigorous fuel,'' said Stewart.</p><p>By Sunday afternoon, the fire had moved to within a kilometre of Ware but Stewart said the townsite is shielded by a river and a swamp. Fire crews hope to save the town by removing fuel ahead of the blaze, she said.</p><p>The residents of Ware, also known as Fort Ware, were taken to the native community to Psykeh, about 100 kilometres south. They were billeted with residents overnight, but all except elders were moved later to a forest service camp equipped with hot showers and cooking facilities, said Stewart.</p><p>Workers from the provincial emergency program and the Social Services Ministry were on hand to help, she said.</p><p>The fire remained out of control Sunday.</p><p>About 60 firefighters, along with bulldozers, water bombers and helicopters, were working to contain the fire. More heavy equipment was en route by barge on Williston Lake.</p><p>Stewart said officials have pinpointed the starting point of the fire but don't know if it accidentally or deliberately set.</p><p>Ware is about 900 kilometres north of Vancouver.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - Marj Oakley knew it was time to leave when burning cinders started raining down on her home near Cowan, Man.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"There was bits of burning stuff flying around in the air," Oakley said in an interview here early today.</p><p>"I felt like I was in Viet Nam with all the waterbombers," said another Cowan resident, Joanne Young. "It was very unsettling."</p><p>The two women were among about 80 Cowan area residents who fled a 40,000-hectare forest fire approaching their town last night. Many spent the night at a curling rink in this nearby village, 400 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg.</p><p>A local state of emergency was declared as the fire levelled one hamlet and moved within a kilometre of Cowan, forcing its evacuation.</p><p>The fire was still raging today but the town was no longer in immediate danger, said Don Keith, a spokesman for the Manitoba Department of Natural Resources</p><p>Burned to ground</p><p>Briggspur, a tiny community with about four families, was destroyed by flames from the 40,000-hectare blaze. "It's burned to the ground," said Emergency Measures Organization spokesman Cindy Stevens, but no one was hurt.</p><p>Albert Driedger, minister responsible for emergency measures, declared a local state of emergency for districts of Mountain and Minitonas, about 200 kilometres northwest of Brandon.</p><p>RCMP were trying to evacuate farms in areas surrounding the heavily forested area, Stevens said.</p><p>More than 100 firefighters, along with 10 helicopters and four water bombers, were trying to control the flames about 50 kilometres (30 miles) east of Swan River.</p><p>Across Manitoba, the weather remained hot and dry but lighter winds enabled firefighters to contain many of the 104 fires, which were concentrated in a belt across south-central Manitoba.</p><p>A fire that forced residents of Manigotagan and several nearby communities on the east shore of Lake Winnipeg to leave their homes had still not been contained, although it had not grown in size.</p><p>Manitoba fires have forced the evacution of about 1,450 people.</p><p>Fires in Ontario</p><p>In Saskatchewan, the situation cooled somewhat as scattered rain helped weary firefighters and light winds slowed the province's 36 fires.</p><p>A fire near Prince Albert, Sask., which caused the death of one man, had grown to 18,500 hectares and was still out of control, but no longer posed a threat to a farming area west of the city, a Saskatchewan parks spokesman said.</p><p>There were five fires burning in Ontario yesterday, all about one hectare in size. The situation was also quiet in British Columbia.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:5SJS-13R1-JDH3-G01S-00000-00New program extends disaster relief for B.C. residents, first to Grand Forks2018-06-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisNEWSNew program extends disaster relief for B.C. residents, first to Grand Forks

The B.C. government has established a new longer-term disaster relief program for B.C. residents affected by floods, fires and other disruptions of their homes and lives.

Premier John Horgan announced the program Wednesday in Grand Forks, where many residents are still not able to move back to their homes after severe flooding of the community in May.

Horgan said the new recovery transition program will provide up to $2,800 over 90 days to cover living expenses of those who have been forced from their homes, in renewable 30-day instalments. The program is administered by the Canadian Red Cross, which provided similar funding for people evacuated from last summer's forest fires.

Horgan urged B.C. residents to donate to the Red Cross flood relief fund, with donations being collected at B.C. liquor stores. The province is matching public donations dollar for dollar.

"It was eye-opening to do a flyover," Horgan said in a conference call from Grand Forks Wednesday afternoon. "We've had public officials on the ground for the past month, making sure that we're preparing to the greatest extent possible to deal with the recovery."

Emergency social services funding was set up to help people forced out by house fires and other local emergencies, and it typically extends for three days. The program has been strained beyond its limits by events such as the widespread forest fire evacuations of 2017, where people were displaced for weeks at a time.

A similar relief program for aboriginal reserves is provided by a federal department, Indigenous Services Canada.

So far the flames have torched 1,100 hectares of timber.</p><p>-BODY- "Obviously, they are all human-caused fires. We haven't had any lightning yet,'' said Rick Strickland, spokesman for the government's forest protection branch.</p><p>"We had some precipitation (Tuesday) throughout most of the province, but we're still in a dry scenario in a large part of central Alberta.</p><p>"It is dry and there was no snow cover in parts of the province.''</p><p>He said most of the fires - including the two still burning - can be blamed on carelessness.</p><p>"There could have been an increase in industrial activity in the forest - cutting pipeline or power lines or whatever, burning a lot of the debris.</p><p>"Or it could be individuals burning garbage or burning grass on private property.</p><p>"They're probably all accidental - not arson fires. Earlier this year, we had a number of fires caused by cigarettes thrown in the ditch.''</p><p>Late last year, a government-commissioned report slammed Alberta Environment saying under-staffed and under-equipped crews weren't prepared for a record number of forest fires in 1998 that cost Alberta taxpayers more than $200 million to fight.</p><p>The KPMG management consultants report released last December said years of budget cuts left the province without enough firefighters and aircraft.</p><p>As a result Alberta had to bring in crews from other provinces at twice the cost.</p><p>The total number of certified firefighters had dropped by one-third since 1993. Fewer than half the lookout towers were manned in May 1998 despite warnings of an early fire season.</p><p>The scathing report prompted Environment Minister Gary Mar to move up the start of the firefighting season to March 1, a month earlier than usual.</p><p>That includes staffing lookout towers in high risk zones and putting special rappel and water bomber units on standby.</p><p>"Lack of snowfall in the province in the previous three years has led to severe dry conditions. This points to a potentially early and aggressive fire season,'' Mar said in February.</p><p>Strickland said as of last week, 10 lookout towers were being staffed and two rappel teams - fast-response squads able to drop into a fire zone from helicopters in extreme emergencies - were stationed in northern Alberta.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5PGT-JFV1-JBVR-3346-00000-00Manitobans going home after fleeing forest fires more than two weeks ago2017-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisNATIONALManitobans going home after fleeing forest fires more than two weeks agoPeople going home after fleeing forest firesThe Canadian Press

WINNIPEG - The Canadian Red Cross is assisting forest fire evacuees return to their homes on the Wasagamack First Nation in Manitoba.

People from three First Nations communities in the Island Lake region were forced from their homes more than two weeks ago by a wildfire.

The Red Cross said the decision to return was made by each First Nation in consultation with the federal government.

It said 1,300 people from Wasagamack First Nation registered with the agency and have been staying in hotels in Brandon and Winnipeg or with friends and family.

Flights for evacuees are scheduled from Brandon and Winnipeg on Saturday and Sunday.

The Wasagamack evacuees are the final group to start the journey home - those from Theresa Point returned earlier this week, while 2,700 people from Garden Hill First Nation began returning on Thursday.

"We know that it has been a long, stressful time for the people of Wasagamack, but it is heartwarming that they will soon be back in their homes and resuming their lives," said Shawn Feely of the Canadian Red Cross.

"We have been happy to work closely with the First Nation leadership to ensure the community members are able to get back home quickly and smoothly."

(CTV Winnipeg)

urn:contentItem:4T9T-TDN0-TX4V-K1CG-00000-00Officials to assess run-off into wells from June forest fire near Halifax2008-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisATLANTIC REGIONAL NEWSOfficials to assess run-off into wells from June forest fire near HalifaxCP

HALIFAX _ Nova Scotia is looking into concerns about the quality of drinking water in an area near Halifax that was damaged by forest fires in June, a cabinet minister confirmed Wednesday.

Tourism Minister Bill Dooks said Environment Department officials would assess the effects of water run-off into wells in the Candy Mountain Road area, near Porters Lake, over the next week.

''If the assessment comes back and there's no concern, then we'll share that with the community,'' said Dooks. ''If the assessment comes back where there is a concern, then we'll have to have a meeting right away to tell people what we're going to do as a government.''

At a community meeting attended by about 40 residents Tuesday, some said forest charred by the blaze is no longer soaking up rain and the run-off is clogging ditches, damaging driveways and running into wells.

Adrian Fuller, district manager with the Environment Department's monitoring and compliance division, said inspectors will examine the extent of erosion and siltation. He said the initial survey would also determine whether the wells in question are drilled or dug.

Fuller said water sources from drilled wells are usually deeper while,those in dug wells are closer to the ground, which could pose a risk.

''But if wells are properly constructed, there shouldn't be any problem with any siltation issues or overland flow ... because they are all supposed to be designed to prevent any siltation from getting into the well,'' said Fuller.

He added the assessment should be completed by the end of next week, at which time officials will have a better idea if additional action is needed.

Dooks, who represents the area in the legislature, said he would distribute a questionnaire to determine the extent of problems faced by homeowners before taking the findings to the government about possible assistance.

''We want the survey completed first ... and at that time, if it warrants attention by government, I'll be calling on my colleagues to bring some support there,'' he said.

The fire destroyed more 1,900 hectares and forced the evacuation of about 5,000 people.

Only two homes were lost in the blaze.

The bill for fighting the fire is estimated to be as high as $800,000.

But after more than 35 millimetres of rain fell in Winnipeg and the surrounding rural areas from Saturday night to late Sunday afternoon and temperatures dipped to 14 C, Enns said the danger of blazes sparking up has been dropped down to "low.''</p><p>"It really breaks that extreme fire behaviour that we've had,'' he said. "It gets right into the forest floor and soaks in.''</p><p>More than 210 square kilometres of land has been scorched this season by 301 fires. About 525 firefighters were on duty around the province, with 31 helicopters and 27 water bombers at their disposal.</p><p>This weekend, 44 fires were listed as active, with three new starts Sunday.</p><p>Enns said he's hoping for a little more rain over the next couple of weeks, before lightning begins to strike from the summer sky.</p><p>Near Thompson, water bombers continued Sunday to target hotspots, but fire officials said difficult terrain conditions coupled with significant ground fires will require extended suppression activities including ground fire mop-up before the fire can declared under control.</p><p>(Winnipeg Sun)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20030518CPCPG0856</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2003</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:48MM-KPY0-01G6-94HN-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="289"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2003 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="18" month="05" year="2003"><dateText>May 18, 2003 Sunday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>ENVIRONMENT; urn:contentItem:5WTW-RTC1-JDH1-C2D0-00000-00Golden Fire Rescue makes trip to Oliver to protect homes from wildfire2019-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisNEWSGolden Fire Rescue makes trip to Oliver to protect homes from wildfire

Four members of Golden Fire Rescue went on a special mission last week to protect homes near a forest fire near Oliver.

Jay LaRoy, Rob Perry, Connor Arnason, and Tom Stevens took the first watch at the Eagle Bluff fire near Oliver after BC Wildfire Services called on August 7.

They arrived in Oliver early in the morning on August 8 to assist. The four firefighters from Golden are highly skilled in wildfire and sprinkler protection, and worked to keep homes in the area safe. They took along Engine 5 for their protection duties.

Sending firefighters to protect homes in areas affected by wildfire is something Golden Fire Rescue deputy Chief Mike Pecora says they do every year.

"Whenever the province calls, we go," he said. "We have the proper truck, and we have the properly qualified crew."

Although the team of four left Golden, the municipality still had adequate firefighters and resources on hand in case of emergency. The fire hall has the most firefighters it has seen in a long time working for Golden Fire Rescue, leaving 21 qualified firefighters to help at home.

"Normally we would only send one or two guys. We have the biggest crew we've ever had," Pecora said, adding that if needed, he could make a call and the truck would return home in the same day.

The Eagle Bluff fire is located approximately 10 kilometres southeast of Okanagan Falls, and is 2,632 hectrares in size. It was discovered on Sunday, August 4.

Previous evacuation orders have been rescinded, and the four firefighters have returned home to Golden.

There are currently 160 firefighters working on the blaze, alongside 14 helicopters, and 19 heavy equipment. During the day, 145 firefighters fight the fire, and 47 work overnight. An incident management team is also in place.

The structure protection teams are no longer stationed through communities as the risk has decreased in those areas, and the fire continues to burn away from communities.

Golden Fire Rescue is constantly working on certifiying and qualifying its members. Recently, BC Wildfire Service trained seven new members, qualifying them to fight wildfires for the province.

Golden has its own structure protection unit, which would be used to protect homes and buildings from a wildfire. The unit is for use in the municipality, Area A, and Revelstoke.

"That actually stays here unless the province calls," Pecora said.

Last year, firefighters LaRoy and Perry joined two Invermere firefighters at the Meachen Creek fire near Kimberley. They were deployed later in August, though Pecora says this year has been a late start to the wildfire season.

"Fire season is really only just starting," he said.

(CP) - Blaming sloppy firefighting for the loss of their homes, residents of a tiny northern Alberta hamlet scorched in a raging forest fire confronted fire officials Wednesday to demand compensation from the province.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Where's his cheque book?'' asked Eugene Paish, referring to Alberta Premier Ralph Klein.</p><p>"Is he going to look after us?'' -BODY-</p><p>Nine homes and numerous other buildings burned to the ground Monday in Chisholm after the homeowners were evacuated. Power remains out in the community about 200 kilometres northwest of Edmonton.</p><p>Many residents blame slipshod firefighting for their losses. Some are insured and some aren't, but all want to know where they can go for help in rebuilding.</p><p>"We lost our homes because of the neglect of Alberta Forestry,'' said Mary Giselbrecht, whose four-year-old home was reduced to a basement full of twisted metal and charred rubble.</p><p>"Is Klein going to pay for us to eat out all the time? The wear and tear on our vehicles? Our phone bills? Mental anguish and whatever else?''</p><p>Her neighbour Barb Romaniuk, now living with her son after her home was burned out, agrees.</p><p>"If we were there with a vehicle and a water truck we could have saved it. (Alberta Forest Service) wasn't there for us.''</p><p>When bad weather prevented Klein's plane from landing for a meeting with the residents, fire officials were left to take the heat.</p><p>"Why did you guys wait so long to get going on this?'' demanded Ron Giselbrecht. "Why didn't you hit it right from the start?</p><p>"You guys don't hit a fire fast.''</p><p>Bruce MacGregor, fire commander, defended the crews' performance.</p><p>The first crews were dispatched within 35 minutes of the fire being reported at 9:35 p.m. on May 23. By 11 p.m. there were 72 firefighters and a water truck at the scene, he said.</p><p>By noon the following day there were 160 firefighters working on the blaze. But Monday's windy weather took matters out of their hands.</p><p>"There wasn't man or beast that could have stopped that fire that night.''</p><p>Back in Edmonton, Klein said some kind of relief will be considered.</p><p>"Certain criteria apply to the declaration of a disaster, and we will have to look at that and make that declaration,'' he said.</p><p>"Then we have to decide the extent of the damage and the extent to which we are able to compensate.''</p><p>Some provincial money is available under the state of emergency declared by the local municipal district, said disaster services official Greg Gramiak.</p><p>The money is available to temporarily house those left homeless by the fire. It may also be used to help the residents rebuild.</p><p>"That possibility is there.''</p><p>Dennis Quintilio, fire behaviour specialist for the Alberta government, said the Chisholm losses were only the second time in 60 years that the Alberta Forest Service has been unable to save homes threatened by a forest fire.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Six stories in the news today from The Canadian Press:

---

FORT MCMURRAY NEIGHBOURHOODS RAZED BY FOREST FIRE

Emergency officials say whole neighbourhoods of Fort McMurray have been destroyed by a raging forest fire that sliced through the middle of the northern Alberta city. Tens of thousands of residents were sent fleeing in both directions, and the entire community of 80,000 was ordered evacuated. Fire chief Darby Allen said there have been no reports of serious injuries.

---

PM TRUDEAU SET TO NAME DATE FOR 'THREE AMIGOS' SUMMIT

Federal sources say Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will formalize the date for the so-called Three Amigos summit at a press conference on Thursday. The summit, which draws together the leaders of Canada, the United States and Mexico, is expected to take place in Ottawa towards the end of June. U.S. President Barack Obama is expected to address Parliament right after the summit.

---

MOUNTIE REACHES SETTLEMENT IN HARASSMENT CASE

A British Columbia Mountie whose sexual harassment lawsuit against the RCMP prompted similar cases across the country has reached an out-of court settlement with the force. Cpl. Catherine Galliford, 49, said she was diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder after going on sick leave in 2006 and was mentally prepared to face a court battle next year before being blindsided by the settlement.

---

KELLY ELLARD DENIED DAY PAROLE

A young woman serving a life sentence for second-degree murder has for the first time taken responsibility for the death of a 14-year-old Vancouver Island girl almost two decades ago, but Kelly Ellard's confession wasn't enough to earn her day parole. In delivering the board's decision, a member commended her for accepting more responsibility but noted her admission did not match the facts of her conviction.

---

MANITOBA PREMIER APPOINTS 12 MEMBER CABINET

Progressive Conservative Brian Pallister was sworn in as Manitoba premier Tuesday and fulfilled an election promise to appoint a smaller cabinet. The new premier appointed eight men and four women - a mixture of veterans and rookies - to his inner circle. He pledged to work hard after the April 19 election that saw the Tories oust a NDP government that had been in power for 17 years.

---

ONTARIO JAILS TO GET FULL-BODY SCANNERS

Ontario says it will use advanced technology to crack down on smuggling of contraband into its 26 adult jails and detention centres, becoming the first province in Canada to install full-body scanners at all of its facilities. The scanners will be installed over two years at a cost of $9.5 million, including maintenance over 10 years. The move follows a six-month pilot project at the Toronto South Detention Centre.

urn:contentItem:5W82-S321-JDH1-C0M8-00000-00Pikangikum First Nation evacuations continue2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A1Pikangikum First Nation evacuations continue1,700 people left fly-in community due to wildfire by SaturdayAlanna Rizza The Canadian Press

Evacuees from Pikangikum First Nation were taken to host cities in two provinces on Sunday while a wildfire continues to grow near the northwestern Ontario community.

The Canadian Armed Forces said late Saturday it had evacuated 1,715 people from the fly-in community 500 kilometres northwest of Thunder Bay, with most landing in Sioux Lookout and Kapuskasing, Ont.

A spokesperson for the town of Sioux Lookout said evacuees who were airlifted on Sunday would be transported to Winnipeg, while most of those who have already arrived in Sioux Lookout would be taken to larger communities, such as Thunder Bay and Timmins.

Brian MacKinnon said about 19 evacuees would be staying in a hotel in Sioux Lookout because being moved again could harm their health, and seven others were in hospital as a precaution.

"We've been working extremely hard to ensure that families stick together and are not broken up," MacKinnon said.

"The evacuees that have come through Sioux Lookout are tired, and of course they're concerned for their community and loved ones. But generally in good spirits, I think, considering the circumstances."

The military said those most at risk from the effects of smoke from the wildfire, such as children and seniors, have already been evacuated.

Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry said the fire, which started on Wednesday, grew to just over 36 square kilometres on Saturday and remains out of control, but favourable winds were keeping it away from the community.

The Manitoba government said in a statement Sunday that it is working with the Ontario and federal governments, as well as the Canadian Red Cross, to co-ordinate temporary housing and services to evacuees.

There was no rain in the Environment Canada forecast for Sunday, but periods of rain are expected Monday and Tuesday. Environment Canada issued a special air-quality statement for the Pikangikum area Sunday morning, warning that people in the vicinity "should be on the lookout for adverse weather conditions and take necessary safety precautions."

Alvin Fiddler, grand chief of the Nishnawbe Aski Nation, has said the forest fire damaged the broadband communications line running through the Pikangikum area, knocking out phone and internet service.

"There's a lot of anxiety, a lot of stress," Fiddler said. "The threat of the fire is still very real."

They also have their own homes and families to worry about."</p><p>The fires have destroyed hundreds of homes and forced the evacuation of thousands of residents in areas in and around Kamloops and Kelowna.</p><p>The grant is part of IFAW's global Emergency Relief effort, which also assisted with the Arizona and Australian wildfires last year, as well as the 1994 Australian wildfires.</p><p>For
