(CP) - Fatigued firefighters and stressed-out residents resigned themselves Saturday to a long campaign as a forest fire that as plagued this Okanagan city for 11 days expanded overnight.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fanned by high winds amid low humidity and temperatures in the mid-30s, the fire swelled east of the city, growing by 500 hectares to 5,500 hectares.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The new front forced crews to retreat hastily, officials said.</p><p>The B.C. Forest Service took some solace, though, from fire crews' success in holding back flames on the north and south fronts of the fire, which has raced through pine and spruce trees and tinder-dry underbrush.</p><p>Firefighters, coping with blisters on their feet and energy-sapping dehydration, maintained their strongest front on the west side closest to the city, where they have constructed fire guards.</p><p>Their efforts are being applauded by area residents in a simple touching gesture - yellow ribbons tied to car aerials.</p><p>On the north and south fronts, about 2,300 residents were on 10-minute evacuation alert, while crews began to rebuild fire guards lost to earlier advances of the fire.</p><p>Forest service officials estimate total firefighting costs exceed $3 million and are mounting by about $200,000 a day.</p><p>"Our goal is to corral it,'' forest resource officer Dennis Gaudry said.</p><p>"We're making gains, slowly but surely. It's going to be a long time. We need a weather change.''</p><p>Residents are hungry for any word on the fire's progress so they can clear out quickly if necessary.</p><p>"We keep going outside to have a look, listen to the radio 24 hours a day and take turns sleeping because we don't know when it's coming,'' said Ron Gust, a carpenter who has lived with his wife and 17-year-old daughter in nearby Naramata for five years.</p><p>He and other worried homeowners arrive in a steady stream to a mobile home that fire officials have set up as a local information centre in this fruit-growing and packing community.</p><p>"It's pretty scary,'' said Linda Smart, a community youth and family worker. "It's more wearing mentally than anything.''</p><p>At least 18 homes have been destroyed since the fire began July 20. Police continued to investigate their suspicion that the fire was deliberately set.</p><p>A total of 393 fires amid 30,000 hectares were burning in the province Saturday.</p><p>In Washington state, firefighters battling stubborn wildfires turned their attention Saturday to a new, explosive blaze that destroyed several canyon homes and crept to within a few kilometres of Leavenworth.</p><p>The Rat Creek blaze started Friday afternoon in the Icicle Creek canyon south of here, about 50 kilometres from a huge fire that threatened homes near the lakeside resort town of Chelan.</p><p>On Friday night, the Rat Creek fire destroyed 14 buildings along the five-kilometre canyon just south of Leavenworth, the Chelan County sheriff's office said. The homes had been evacuated, and no one was injured.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier James Johnston of the Lethbridge detatchment.</p><p>Samantha Grant, a spokeswoman for STARS air ambulance, said an 80-year-old woman was flown from the Fort Macleod hospital to Calgary with second-and-third-degree burns.</p><p>All 350 residents of Granum and another 250 people from the surrounding area were sent to neighboring Claresholm as a grass fire burned close to the town, about 130 kilometres south of Calgary.</p><p>However, most were allowed to return home later in the evening after the danger had passed.</p><p>Claresholm Mayor Ernie Patterson said not all residents of the region were as lucky: "There are some families who have lost their homes. It's just been a calamity.''</p><p>Stan Byers and his wife Clara saw their place outside the village burn to the ground.</p><p>"I just don't know what we are going to do. Other people get to go home now, but where do we go? Nowhere,'' said a shocked Stan Byers. "I just stood there looking for that ray of hope the fire would pass by the house.''</p><p>Patterson said firefighting efforts and a lucky shift in the wind stopped the blaze right on the edge of Granum.</p><p>"We've had no snow,'' Patterson said of local conditions. "The forest fire hazard is extremely high.''</p><p>The blaze, which fire officials said had burned 100 square kilometres of land, also forced the closure of Highway 2 and prompted women and children to flee the Keho Hutterite colony.</p><p>It was a sad scene at the Claresholm high school, where about 60 evacuees awaited the chance to return to Granum. Many hugged and cried as they consoled each other.</p><p>"I'm holding out hope, that's all I can do,'' said long-time Granum resident Ray Raine, who took his dog Bernie with him as he fled his home.</p><p>Eileen Cooper of Barons, a town just east of Granum, said the fire was an eerie sight.</p><p>"While the sun was out we could see what seemed like a mixture of billowing sand and smoke. At one time the sun was rust-red,'' she said.</p><p>One of the fires at Hinton, 300 kilometres west of Edmonton, was believed to have started Saturday night when an electrical pole toppled over and was fuelled by winds of up to 80 kilometres an hour.</p><p>Rocky Notnes saw his two-storey log home burn to the ground, along with a garage and several cars.</p><p>"We just woke up because the house was filling with smoke,'' he said. "We went outside and saw the fire. The wind was so strong we knew it could come this way, and then as we were speaking, there was just fire literally dropping from the sky.</p><p>"We headed straight down to the river in the moonlight. It's a miracle that no one was killed.'' Firefighter Perry Hayward said the winds were unbelievably strong.</p><p>"It was really jumping all over the place. It was bad enough that some residents of Hinton were told to be ready to evacuate at any time if the wind shifted.''</p><p>Most veteran firefighters said they had never worked on a forest fire this late in the year.</p><p>"I was supposed to be decorating the Christmas tree and then going ice-fishing,'' said Dave Lind of Lac La Biche. "But it looks like I won't be back for maybe a week or so. We need the winds to calm down before we get this one under control.''</p><p>Evert Smith of Alberta's Land and Forest Service said one of the two fires covered 500 hectares north of the community. The second blaze, about 1,500 hectares in size, blazed about 30 kilometres south of the town.</p><p>Six water tankers, four helicopters and eight ground crews were fighting the fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:590V-9BR1-F03R-N1Y1-00000-00Hundreds evacuated in Mallorca due to out-of-control forest fires2013-07-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisHundreds evacuated in Mallorca due to out-of-control forest fires

Jul 28, 2013 (Digital Journal:http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex)
700 people have been evacuated from the town of Estellencs in the west of Mallorca as a fierce forest fire rages out of control. 300 firefighters from all over the island are fighting the blaze.


The fire[1] started two days ago near Andraitx and rapidly burned through the pine and oak forest above the town.

The Mallorca Daily Bulletin[2] reported that the whole of the Sa Coma 'Frio' valley in the hills above Andraitx town seemed to be on fire. They reported that the forest blaze was moving at 'astonishing speed.'
It has since then blazed through an area of over 2,000 hectares and is the worst fire on the island since 1999.

According to security forces in Mallorca, the blaze is still not under control.
Temperatures of around 40 degrees Celsius in the shade combined with high winds are making the fire move faster and it is very difficult to contain.
Apparently there has been virtually no rain in the area for at least two months, making conditions very dry.
300 firefighters[3] together with fire fighting planes and helicopters have been deployed to douse the flames.

urn:contentItem:5W7N-CMW1-DY9S-T3DJ-00000-00Evacuations continue as fire threat to Pikangikum First Nation grows2019-06-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisONTARIOEvacuations continue as fire threat to Pikangikum First Nation growsPikangikum evacuations ramp up as fire growsMichelle McQuiggeThe Canadian Press

Evacuation efforts in Pikangikum First Nation are ramping up as a wildfire threatening the northern Ontario community gains strength and cripples local telecom services.

Alvin Fiddler, Grand Chief of the Nishnawbe Aski Nation, which represents 49 First Nation communities across northern Ontario, said a forest fire burning near the eastern edge of the fly-in community has grown in the past 24 hours.

He said it has damaged the broadband communications line running through the area, knocking out all phone and internet service.

Ontario's Ministry of the Solicitor General is working with the Royal Canadian Airforce to fly Pikangikum residents to nearby communities.

Fiddler said he was hoping at least 1,200 people would be airlifted from the community on Friday.

However, at the end of the day the military said in a release that 580 people had been evacuated aboard three Hercules aircraft during six flights to surrounding communities including Sioux Lookout and Kapuskasing.

The release said the military would continue to provide aircraft for further evacuations as needed.

Fiddler said favourable wind conditions had given residents a respite from heavy smoke on Friday and opened a crucial window for evacuation.

He noted the list of vulnerable residents includes the elderly, those with respiratory conditions, young children, and anyone else whose presence is required to support them.

The community, which is 500 kilometres northwest of Thunder Bay, Ont., planned to evacuate roughly 1,600 of its nearly 2,300 residents, Fiddler said.

However, Solicitor General spokesman Brent Ross said he couldn't confirm the number of potential evacuees, citing the "fluidity of the situation."

Sioux Lookout is acting as a "hub airport," Ross said in a statement.

"Smaller fixed wing aircraft operated by private carriers on behalf of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry will then be used to take the evacuees from Sioux Lookout to Cochrane, which is acting as a host community."

The Ministry of Natural Resources said four waterbombers and 14 ground crews were working to battle the blaze, estimated at around 3,000 hectares.

Environment Canada has issued a special air quality statement for the Pikangikum area, warning residents could experience symptoms such as coughing, headaches or shortness of breath.

"Children, seniors and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk," the agency said, adding the northerly winds should help improve conditions in Pikangikum but blow smoke towards communities further south.

urn:contentItem:5W47-V7S1-JBVR-31G3-00000-00Review: Danger, beauty, suspense in 'The River's' wilderness2019-05-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisENTERTAINMENTReview: Danger, beauty, suspense in 'The River's' wildernessReview: Danger, beauty, suspense in 'The River's' wildernessJulia RubinThe Associated Press

"The River," by Peter Heller (Alfred A. Knopf)

This novel about two Dartmouth College students on a canoe trip gone badly awry is partly an ode to the Northern wilderness, partly a survival how-to, and mostly a thriller - suspenseful and gut-wrenching.

Best friends Wynn and Jack take a late-summer trip to Canada, paddling down a river that winds through lakes and over rapids on its way to Hudson Bay. Like the river, author Peter Heller's plot often takes its time, digressing to describe how the boys fillet a fish or make camp, or what the Northern Lights look like. But don't get lulled: There's action around the bend.

The two friends, both country boys, are experts in the woods and on the water, where they are self-proclaimed "minimalists" - no phones, no frills. They also share "a literary way of looking at the world," and frequently see it through the lenses of Edgar Allan Poe, Virgil, James Dickey and more.

Their leisurely trip turns into a harrowing dash toward safety when both nature and other people turn violent. Nature dishes up a massive forest fire that bears down on them. The boys smell and hear the blaze long before they see it - the fleeing animals, the drifting smoke, the popping and hissing of trees.

Meanwhile, human mysteries lurk: Wynn and Jack hear a man and woman arguing on the bank as their canoe glides by in the fog; when they return to warn the couple about the fire, they find nobody there. Later, a man turns up at their camp downriver, alone. Where is the woman?

Heller, author of previous novels including "The Dog Stars" and "Celine," dives deep into the details of wilderness camping - so deep that sometimes you just want to jump ahead and find out what happens. Likewise with his acute and poetic observations of nature. But he is setting the scene and establishing two likable and memorable characters in Wynn and Jack. Each brings a different perspective to the violence and tragedy they encounter.

River travel has often been a metaphor for writers. At one point early on, as the boys approach some rapids, Heller writes that "every river story they had ever read was just beneath the surface of their imaginations and must have fired them with extra energy and braced them, too, because at least half of those stories did not have happy endings."

One of the biggest - Thunder Bay Fire 21 - is burning out of control near Lake Nipigon.</p><p>"We haven't seen a decent rain since last year," said Mitch Miller, a fire information officer at the Ontario natural resources ministry's Fire Management Centre in Dryden.</p><p>"We don't have any rain in the forecast, so things are going to get worse before they get any better."</p><p>Miller said the unusually dry conditions mean the fires are burning both above and below ground, making the 10 that are still burning devilishly difficult to control and extinguish.</p><p>"It's so dry the fire is actually burning into the ground, and that means our fire rangers are having to spend more time on the fire to make sure that they dig out all the hot spots before they're declared out," he said.</p><p>"Under these conditions we've seen explosive fire growth."</p><p>The global phenomenon known as El Nino - a massive warming of Pacific Ocean water that has wreaked weather havoc around the globe - is just one of the causes for the drought-like conditions, said Environment Canada forecaster Jack Dennahower.</p><p>"By this time of year it should be pouring rain up there in Northern Ontario," he said. "But this seems to be that particular year when they're not getting anything."</p><p>Thunder Bay, the bull's-eye of the bone-dry northwestern forests, was placed under an open burning ban by the ministry Friday.</p><p>The ban extends from Lake Nipigon's western shores to the Manitoba border, and from the U.S.-Canada boundary north 400 kilometres to the Pickle Lake region.</p><p>Environment Canada climatologist Sandi Radecki said the Thunder Bay region has had an unusually dry April, with only 4.2 millimetres of precipitation.</p><p>"Normally they should be getting 47 millimetres of precipitation in April - they've had less than a 10th of that."</p><p>Although southern Ontario had a wetter-than-normal March - offset only slightly by somewhat drier conditions than usual in April - the fire danger remains a cause for concern to officials.</p><p>Several weeks without significant rainfall in the Parry Sound area led two fire departments - Parry Sound and Seguin Township just to the south - to impose bans on open burning until further notice.</p><p>"I won't lift the fire ban here until we get at least 24 hours of steady rain," said Parry Sound Fire Chief Garnet Schenk.</p><p>In Seguin Township, which takes in a vast area stretching from Parry Sound south to Mactier, and from Georgian Bay to the Muskoka Lakes in the east, Fire Chief Abe Kamerman had lifted the ban for several weeks.</p><p>But, "at this point I can't take the risk with it so dry," Kamerman said.</p><p>A worry, he added, are the thousands of seasonal residents who are headed up to clean out their cottages and tidy up their yards.</p><p>"Many seasonal residents are coming into the area to clean their cottages now," Kamerman said.</p><p>"I wanted to make sure the fire ban was in place A2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Thousands flee forest fire near Jerusalem</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEWE ILAN, ISRAEL</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fires fanned by hot desert winds burned near Jerusalem yesterday, scorching 1,000 hectares (2,500 acres) of forest and forcing the evacuation of thousands of people from six small towns.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Police were investigating both arson and negligence as possible causes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Forestry officials said it was the biggest fire in Israel's 47-year history. They estimated the fire had done more than $27 million Cdn damage to forests alone, destroying two million trees.</p><p>At least 37 people were admitted to hospital for smoke inhalation and two were reported in serious condition.</p><p>A large cloud of grey smoke hovered over the Jerusalem area. Ashes fell in downtown Jerusalem and the smell of smoke permeated the city.</p><p>HIGHWAY CLOSED</p><p>The main highway between Tel Aviv and Jerusalem was closed for several hours because of flames shooting into the air about eight kilometres (five miles) west of Jerusalem. Traffic was backed up and at a standstill in many parts of Jerusalem as motorists were unable to get out of the city.</p><p>Hundreds of firefighters and dozens of fire engines called in from all over Israel needed more than six hours to control the blaze. Four planes and military helicopters sprayed chemicals on the flames.</p><p>As flames approached, residents were evacuated from a cluster of towns several kilometres west of Jerusalem -- Newe Ilan, Shoresh, Shoeva, Telstone, Kiriyat Yaarim and Yad Hashmona.</p><p>Israel radio said 20 homes and a small hotel were destroyed in Shoresh and another 10 homes damaged.</p><p>In Telstone, a small community of ultra-Orthodox Jews, dozens of people left on foot. Some women pushed baby strollers loaded with suitcases, and one man in a black coat and hat carried a Torah scroll in his arms. Others got into buses.</p><p>Along a section of the main highway, flames shot 18 metres (57 feet) into the air and employees at a gas station hosed down fuel tanks with water. Police vans blocked the road, barring motorists from driving past the fire.</p><p>"I propose that anyone who does not urgently need to get out of Jerusalem or go to Jerusalem stay home," said Ido Gutmann, head of traffic police.</p><p>Record temperatures were measured in much of Israel yesterday. In Tel Aviv, temperatures rose to 37 C (98.6 F), the highest for the day since 1884, meteorologists said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - About 150 people were forced from their remote Northern Ontario homes early Thursday after a forest fire burned within a kilometre of the town of Peawanuk.</p><p nitf:lede="true">While forest fires in the Prairies and B.C. appeared to stabilize, two Hercules aircraft were called in to help airlift people from the community on Hudson's Bay to Timmins - a 2 1/2-hour flight away.</p><p>-BODY- Some 40 people refused to leave town, including the band chief, and decided to fight the flames instead.</p><p>It's expected it will take about three days for the area to clear.</p><p>"I'm thinking this fire is in good shape and could see . . . people being back in their community by the weekend,'' said Dan Johnson, the Ministry of Natural Resources fire technician called in to handle the fire.</p><p>Some 15 firefighters were still trying to get the fire under control Thursday afternoon.</p><p>"Crews are making excellent progress,'' said Johnson. "The weather and weather forecast has really assisted us in our effort.''</p><p>Johnson said some nine millimetres of rain fell Wednesday night.</p><p>The fire spread to 100 hectares and crept to within a kilometre of the town on the Weenuska First Nation reserve when the acting chief declared an emergency.</p><p>Johnson said the fire was still within a kilometre of Peawanuk on Thursday afternoon but felt there was no danger of it spreading further due to the direction of the winds.</p><p>The McIntyre Curling Club and Spruce Hill Manor, located within the old Timmins hospital in South Porcupine, have been converted into shelter facilities.</p><p>Margaret Mack, a Peawanuck band council member, said many of the community's residents were unwilling to leave until it became obvious their lives were in danger.</p><p>Flames were visible to those in the community and the "smoke was so dense, you could barely breathe,'' she said.</p><p>She said some people didn't want to leave their dogs behind.</p><p>"We could only bring two bags each, enough for a change of clothes, medication and baby stuff.''</p><p>Mack said this is the third time since 1986 that natural disaster has forced the evacuation of Peawanuck.</p><p>Massive ice flows forced people to leave their homes in the spring of 1997, and a flood destroyed most of the community in 1986. (Timmins Daily Press)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4PN1-7YK0-TX4V-K154-00000-006 firefighters, including young volunteers, die battling forest fire in Croatia2007-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisFOREIGN GENERAL NEWS6 firefighters, including young volunteers, die battling forest fire in CroatiaSNJEZANA VUKICAP

ZAGREB, Croatia (AP) _ The prime minister promised an investigation Friday into Croatia's worst firefighting disaster, in which six men were killed and seven badly injured when they were trapped battling a fierce forest blaze.

The group _ including volunteers aged 17 and 18 _ was encircled by flames Thursday when the wind suddenly changed direction while they were fighting a fire on Kornat island, national firefighting chief Mladen Jurin said.

Police said eight men had been detained on suspicion of arson. The state-run news agency HINA said the eight were seasonal construction and tourism workers. They were allegedly filmed setting the fire by a German tourist.

The fire was brought under control early Friday.

The victims had been among 23 firefighters initially sent to fight the Kornat blaze. The 13 went to confront flames threatening homes on the island but were trapped when the fire changed course and surrounded them.

Women and children were jumping into the sea as the fire approached their homes, firefighter Nikola Kurkut told the Croatian daily newspaper Vecernji List.

Five of the seven wounded had life-threatening injuries, with burns covering 85 per cent to 90 per cent of their bodies, and they were transferred overnight to two clinics in Zagreb, doctors said.

Prime Minister Ivo Sanader visited the injured in the coastal city of Zadar, saying it was the ''biggest tragedy in Croatian firefighting.''

''The government insists on a thorough investigation,'' he said. If it was arson, the government wants the ''perpetrators to be identified and harshly punished,'' he said.

President Stipe Mesic demanded an inquiry into the actions of firefighting commanders, saying they ''should have left a way for their retreat.''

Jurin defended his colleagues and said the incident was part of ''the risks of our job.''

The government set Monday as a national day of mourning.

The county governor said the dead included a 17-year-old and two 18-year-old volunteer firefighters. The others were professional firefighters. The injured also included both volunteers and professionals.

Kornat is the biggest island in the archipelago of Kornati, off central Croatia in the Adriatic Sea. Dozens of small islands, mostly uninhabited and surrounded by clear blue water, are popular with tourists.

Croatia has battled a record 1,500 fires this summer, mostly in forests. The only other casualty this year was a firefighter who died Wednesday after falling ill while putting out fires on another island.

"We're looking at every angle. We're not going to close the season if at all possible.</p><p>"The province's outfitters have booked hunters from as far away as Asia. It would have to be pending on a near isaster before we close it.''</p><p>The driest fall in 30 years has left the woods parched. There have been 70 new fires in the past week and bans on campfires, burning permits and wood harvesting between noon and 6 p.m. remain in effect.</p><p>"We've got about 15 fires that are burning this morning,'' said Wade Wilson, a spokesman in Graham's department.</p><p>"It's taking a long time to declare some of these fires officially out. We're hoping for some rain later in the week.''</p><p>There are 400 people fighting fires across the province.</p><p>Officials believe most of the fires have been caused by people and mostly by accident. But Graham also thinks a handful of fires have been set deliberately by poachers to distract game wardens.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5GGS-K691-JDN4-N0YC-00000-00Athabasca Nuclear Corporation Announces Regulatory Decisions2015-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:00ZLexisNexisAthabasca Nuclear Corporation Announces Regulatory Decisions

(via Thenewswire.ca)

Vancouver, BC / TheNewswire / July 20, 2015 - Athabasca Nuclear Corporation (TSX-V: ASC) ("Athabasca Nuclear" or the "Corporation") reports that the Government of Saskatchewan has granted regulatory relief to the Corporation (the "Regulatory Decisions") with respect to Athabasca Nuclear's Wollaston NE and Preston Projects (the "Properties") located in Northern Saskatchewan.

The Regulatory Decisions follow government reviews and legal submissions made by Athabasca Nuclear with respect to the unprecedented forest fire situation in Saskatchewan. Athabasca Nuclear reports that there is substantial forest fire activity and risk occurring where the Corporation's mineral tenure is located.

As a result of the Regulatory Decision, the Corporation advises that work requirements for the current assessment period at the Properties has been satisfied by way of regulatory relief. The approximate area for which relief has been granted is 209,000 hectares.

"Athabasca Nuclear stands with the Government of Saskatchewan in recognizing the gravity of the forest fires impacting Northern Saskatchewan. Our thoughts are with the affected communities and we commend the resilient spirit of the people of Saskatchewan and first responders. We believe the leadership displayed by the Government of Saskatchewan in ensuring that the mineral exploration industry minimizes its footprint during this sensitive period of time is well-founded. Moreover, we wish to acknowledge the Government of Saskatchewan's exemplary commitment to public safety," stated Ryan Kalt, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Athabasca Nuclear.

The Corporation advises that it may also receive further relief on additional mineral tenure.

About Athabasca Nuclear Corporation

Athabasca Nuclear Corporation (TSXV:ASC) is an exploration company focused primarily on uranium exploration near the Athabasca Basin in Saskatchewan, Canada, and other select opportunities. More information about Athabasca Nuclear and its projects may be found at www.athabascanuclear.com.

urn:contentItem:470S-H9S0-01G6-81Y8-00000-00<published>1994-09-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:00Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PM-Mba-Fire-Evacuate, Bgt ; UNDATED - Budget; See Leaf Rapids Night; With UNDATED Quickfacts; Forest fire forces people from northern Manitoba town</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Mary Jo Laforest</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>The Canadian Press Innkeepers down the road from the northern Manitoba town of Leaf Rapids readied rooms Sunday evening as dense smoke from a nearby forest fire drove 1,600 people from their homes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"I'm doing a lot of baking right now,'' said Hilda Merasty, who was preparing bread and cookies for evacuees at the Friendship Centre in Lynn Lake, about an hour's drive northwest of Leaf Rapids.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Almost everyone in Leaf Rapids was given two hours to pack and leave when the fire swept to within three kilometres of the community, town administrator Ernie Epp said Sunday night.</p><p>Only essential workers were to remain in the town, about 1,000 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg.</p><p>Dick Bon, duty officer for the provincial forest fire office, said the fire had cut off the two-lane, gravel road that links Leaf Rapids to Thompson. That meant people had to flee 100 kilometres north to Lynn Lake.</p><p>It's a scenario that has been played out several times over the years, with each town helping the other when fire threatens.</p><p>Last summer, a massive fire forced 850 residents of Lynn Lake to seek shelter in Leaf Rapids and Thompson.</p><p>In 1989, more than 1,000 residents from Leaf Rapids bunked with Lynn Lake families when fires forced them to flee their homes.</p><p>Sheldon Lambe, his pregnant wife Margie and 2 1/2-year-old daughter Jessica got one of the last hotel rooms available Sunday night in Lynn Lake.</p><p>"It's been a pretty harrowing night,'' Lambe said. His wife is already a few days overdue, he added.</p><p>"We packed whatever we could squeeze in the car, right down to my daughter's Barney.''</p><p>A lightning strike may have started the fire Saturday amid unseasonably hot, dry conditions, according to Epp. However, Bon said forestry officials suspect it was man-made.</p><p>"The fire started (Saturday) on about 25 hectares or so,'' he said. "Unfortunately, it got away on the ground crew.''</p><p>By Sunday, the blaze was out of control and had spread over 2,000 hectares. Water bombers that were scheduled to be put away for the winter and routine maintenance were hurried into service.</p><p>People in Leaf Rapids, a town surrounded by dense woods on the banks of the Churchill River, were warned earlier Sunday on the local cable television channel to be prepared to leave.</p><p>"It looked like thunderclouds,'' Lambe said of the thick smoke enveloping the town.</p><p>There were long lineups at gas pumps as people rushed to gas stations to fill up their vehicles for the hour-long drive north to Lynn Lake.</p><p>When winds started to shift, Epp - who is also the town's emergency co-ordinator - ordered residents to evacuate.</p><p>Lambe, who works at the Hudson Bay Mining Company's Ruttan Mine, said officials closed the mine before the evacuation notice was given.</p><p>And when it came, Lambe's family was ready. Besides clothes, they also packed their wedding videos and pictures - "things that if they're lost, they're gone forever,'' Lambe said.</p><p>"I just bought a new house, I'm hoping they can contain it.''</p><p>Volunteers went door-to-door alerting people to leave town and fire trucks cruised the streets blaring the same message.</p><p>Evacuees booked ahead for rooms at Lynn Lake's two hotels. Others were to be put up at the Friendship Centre, the town's high school gym and at private residences, said the centre's Merasty.</p><p>And she was ready for them. "We'll probably have a good time.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
